dct:title: Miami-Dade Sex Offenders
dct:creator: Miami Dade County
dct:license: Miami-Dade County provides this data for use "as is". The areas depicted by this map/data are approximate, and are not accurate to surveying or engineering standards. The maps/data shown here are for illustration purposes only and are not suitable for site-specific decision making. Information found here should not be used for making financial or any other commitments. Miami-Dade County provides this information with the understanding that it is not guaranteed to be accurate, correct or complete and conclusions drawn from such information are the sole responsibility of the user. While every effort has been made to ensure the accuracy, correctness and timeliness of materials presented, Miami-Dade County assumes no responsibility for errors or omissions, even if Miami-Dade County is advised of the possibility of such damage.
dct:description: A point feature class of Sexual Offenders and Predators within Miami-Dade County that is used by the Sexual Offender/Predator Residence Search Internet application.
prov:action:
#########
# GDSC ETL is performed in two steps: shell script to ETL data into postgres
# and then additional transformations with SQL in postGIS (if needed).
####

#########
# Step 1 - bash script (pseudo code)
####

# create directory structure and move into it
mkdir -p /data/mdc_sexual_predators/{download,etl} && cd /data/mdc_sexual_predators

# set update flag based on last update and update frequency
do_update=0 if date() < last_update + update_frequency else do_update = 1

# download if update flag is set:
if do_update == 1 then
  ogr2ogr -nln mdc_sexual_predators download/mdc_sexual_predators.json "https://services.arcgis.com/8Pc9XBTAsYuxx9Ny/arcgis/rest/services/SEXPRED_gdb/FeatureServer/0/query?outFields=*&where=1%3D1&outSR=4326&f=geojson"

# replace column names Shape__Length and Shape__Area to avoid conflict when
# providing as service on ArcServer.
sed -i 's/Shape__Length/shape_length/gI; s/Shape__Area/shape_area/gI' download/mdc_sexual_predators.json

# load into postGIS with:
  ogr2ogr -lco GEOMETRY_NAME=geom -f PostgreSQL PG:"<postgres connection>" download/mdc_sexual_predators.json -nlt point -nln mdc_sexual_predators

#########
# Step 2 - SQL script (pseudo code):
####

# remove duplicate points and make geometries valid:
UPDATE mdc_sexual_predators
  SET geom=ST_MakeValid(ST_RemoveRepeatedPoints(geom));"

# add local geometry column and reproject existing geometries into local EPSG:
SELECT AddGeometryColumn (
  'mdc_sexual_predators',
  'geom_local',2236,'point',2
);
UPDATE mdc_sexual_predators
  SET geom_local=ST_MakeValid(ST_RemoveRepeatedPoints(ST_Transform(geom,2236)));
CREATE INDEX mdc_sexual_predators_geom_local_idx
  ON mdc_sexual_predators
  USING GIST (geom_local);
NOTIFY pgrst, 'reload schema';"cd /data/mdc_sexual_predators/
mkdir -p derived
# Create pg_dump and downloadable zip of table in derivate directory 
pg_dump -d $POSTGRES_DB -U $POSTGRES_USER -p $POSTGRES_PORT -h postgis-tt1sk6l8tqln1op3 -t mdc_sexual_predators > derived/mdc_sexual_predators.sql
tar -czf derived/mdc_sexual_predators.sql.tar.gz meta_dcat_mdc_sexual_predators.json -C derived mdc_sexual_predators.sql
dcat:contactPoint: University of Miami Libraries, Frost Institute for Data Science and Computing
